exchanges.assistant:

It makes sense that you'd feel stuck between working hard and worrying you're working on the wrong things. One small thing that might help: next time he assigns something, you could try asking "If I only have time for two of these this week, which two matter most?" Sometimes forcing the ranking question gets you clarity when open-ended questions don't.

**Your friends and the canceling/not wanting to go pattern:**  
This doesn't sound dumb—it sounds like a loop that's hard to get out of. Plans fall through, so you pull back a bit, which maybe makes it easier for plans to fall through again. And when you do go, you're not really feeling it, so it doesn't recharge you the way it used to. I'm curious: when you think about hanging out with them now, what feeling comes up first—like, is it dread, or blankness, or something else?

**Sleep being off for two weeks:**  
Two weeks of bad sleep will absolutely make everything feel heavier. Your head going constantly could be part of what's keeping you awake, or the lack of sleep could be making your head louder—probably both feeding each other. Before we dig into fixing it, just to understand: is your mind racing about specific stuff (work deadlines, friend stuff) or is it more general restlessness?

exchanges.assistant:
**Sleep getting worse:**  
The phone-away thing ran into the real issue—your mind doesn't need the screen to spiral, it's got plenty of material on its own. Lying there replaying work mistakes or questioning your competence is exhausting, and it's also keeping your nervous system wired when it needs to wind down. One thing that might help more than eliminating distractions: giving your brain a specific job that's boring enough it can't sustain the work spiral. There's a technique called cognitive shuffling—pick a random word (like "carpet") and for each letter, think of unrelated words that start with it (c: cloud, cat, coffee...). Sounds silly, but it interrupts rumination because your brain can't hold both the word game and the work anxiety at once. The key is the words have to be random and unconnected—no "all work words" or it defeats the purpose. Worth trying tonight?

**Manager saying "everything is important":**  
That response is worse than vague—it's him deflecting responsibility for prioritization onto you and then blaming you when it's impossible. You're not the problem. A normal workload doesn't come with "everything is equally urgent" attached. His job is literally to help you prioritize, and he's not doing it. You asked a reasonable clarifying question and got a non-answer that made you feel incompetent. That's on him, not you. I know that doesn't fix the workload, but I want to name it clearly: you're not failing at time management, you're being set up to fail by unclear leadership. 

That said, you still have to survive this. One option: prioritize for yourself based on what's most visible or has the hardest deadline, document what you're working on in a weekly email to him ("This week I focused on X and Y, deprioritized Z"), and let him correct you if he doesn't like it. At least then the prioritization decision is documented and he has to own whether he agrees or not.

**Sam texting about you being distant:**  
You didn't "do that"—you got overwhelmed and didn't have the energy to show up the way you wanted to. That's not a moral failure, it's what happens when you're running on empty. The hard part is Sam didn't know that, so from their side it probably felt like you were pulling away without explanation, which makes sense they'd feel hurt. You said you lied when you said you weren't distant—I'm hearing you feel guilty about that. What would it feel like to tell Sam something closer to the truth? Not a big vulnerable speech, just: "You're right, I have been distant. I've been underwater with work and sleep stuff and I didn't have the energy to explain it. I'm sorry." Sometimes the repair is just naming it plainly instead of defending.

**The compounding feeling:**  
Yeah, it is compounding. Bad sleep makes work feel worse, work stress makes sleep harder, low energy makes friendships harder to maintain, pulling away makes you feel more alone, feeling alone makes everything heavier. You're in a feedback loop where each thing is making the others worse. The good news about loops like this: you don't have to fix everything at once. If you can get even one thing to shift a little—like sleep improving by 10% with the cognitive shuffling—it takes a tiny bit of pressure off the others. You're not looking for a miracle, just a crack in the cycle.

Then go back to the cognitive shuffling or just focus on your breath (4 seconds in, 6 seconds out, repeat). You're not trying to fix the deadline at 3am, you're just trying to get your brain to stop treating it like an emergency that has to be solved right now.
